critical_issues.impact: No scaffolding for youngest learners while T21-T23 have K-2
Title says 'Generative AI' but 79% of skills are XO-only
critical_issues.fix: Add ChatGPT block skills (5) and DALL-E skills (3)

critical_issues.impact: All G8 skills depend on G5 skills (3-grade gap)
critical_issues.fix: Remove explicit G5 dependencies, rely on transitive closure

critical_issues.impact: Average 6.4 dependencies per skill, many unnecessary
critical_issues.fix: Reduce to 2-3 essential dependencies per skill

critical_issues.impact: No explicit skill for testing AI-generated code

new_skills.title: Helpers Can Answer Questions
new_skills.description_teacher: Students match pictures of different helpers (teacher, parent, robot, computer) to questions they can answer. They learn that computers can be helpers too.
new_skills.student_prompt: Match the helper to the question!
new_skills.rationale: K-2 foundation: Introduces concept of AI assistant at developmentally appropriate level

new_skills.title: Ask XO a Simple Question
new_skills.description_teacher: Students click on XO and ask a simple question (e.g., 'What color is the sky?'). They learn that XO can answer questions just like a person.
new_skills.rationale: K-2 foundation: First hands-on interaction with XO

new_skills.title: XO Can Help with Different Things
new_skills.description_teacher: Students match different types of questions (math, spelling, ideas for a project) to pictures showing how XO can help. They learn XO can help in many ways.
new_skills.rationale: K-2 foundation: Broadens understanding of AI assistant capabilities

new_skills.title: Ask XO for Help When Stuck
new_skills.description: When stuck on a simple coding task (e.g., 'How do I make my sprite jump?'), a student asks XO for help. XO provides a suggestion. The student tries it and sees if it works. This introduces XO as a helpful resource for getting unstuck.
new_skills.rationale: G3 entry: Simpler entry point than 'review algorithm'

new_skills.title: Use ChatGPT Block to Ask a Question
new_skills.description: Students use a ChatGPT block in their code to ask a simple question and display the answer (e.g., ask 'What is a fun fact about dinosaurs?' and show response). They learn that AI can be integrated directly into their projects, not just used through XO.
new_skills.rationale: Expansion: First ChatGPT block skill, bridges XO and direct AI use

new_skills.title: Generate Test Data with ChatGPT
new_skills.description: Students use ChatGPT blocks to generate test data for their projects (e.g., 'Generate 5 random animal names' or 'Create 3 quiz questions about space'). They learn that AI can help with content creation during development.
new_skills.rationale: Expansion: ChatGPT as coding tool, not just user-facing feature

new_skills.title: Generate Placeholder Art with DALL-E
new_skills.description: While prototyping a game, students use DALL-E blocks to quickly generate placeholder sprites or backdrops without leaving the coding environment. They learn that AI can speed up the development process.
new_skills.rationale: Expansion: DALL-E in coding workflow (vs. T21 for art creation)

new_skills.title: Test XO-Generated Code Before Using It
new_skills.description: When XO suggests code, a student tests it thoroughly before adding it to their project: (1) Does it run without errors? (2) Does it do what I asked? (3) Does it break other parts of my project? They learn that AI-generated code must be verified, not blindly trusted.
new_skills.rationale: Critical missing skill: Verification of AI-generated code

new_skills.title: Use ChatGPT to Explain Complex Code
new_skills.description: Students use ChatGPT blocks to create an in-project code explanation system: paste a code snippet into ChatGPT and get an explanation. They learn to use AI for documentation and learning.

new_skills.title: Generate Multiple Design Options with DALL-E
new_skills.description: Students generate 3-4 variations of an asset using DALL-E with different prompts, compare them, and select the best fit for their project. They learn iterative design with AI assistance.

new_skills.title: Attach Project Snapshots to XO Conversations
new_skills.description: When asking XO for help, students attach a snapshot of their project so XO can see their stage/sprites/code. They learn that visual context helps AI provide better assistance.

new_skills.title: Stream ChatGPT Responses in Real-Time
new_skills.description: Students use streaming ChatGPT blocks to show AI responses being generated word-by-word, creating a more engaging user experience. They understand the difference between streaming and non-streaming APIs.

new_skills.title: Refine AI-Generated Assets for Production
new_skills.description: Students generate assets with DALL-E, evaluate them critically, identify what needs improvement, and either refine the prompt or edit the image manually. They learn that AI is a starting point, not a final product.

new_skills.title: Use Multimodal ChatGPT to Analyze Images
new_skills.description: Students use multimodal ChatGPT blocks to analyze images in their projects (e.g., 'Describe what's in this image' or 'What colors are dominant?'). They learn that AI can process both text and images.

new_skills.title: Combine Multiple AI Tools in One Project
new_skills.description: Students build a project that uses 2+ AI tools together (e.g., speech recognition → ChatGPT → text-to-speech, or face detection → DALL-E → display). They learn to orchestrate multiple AI capabilities.

new_skills.title: Manage ChatGPT Conversation Context
new_skills.description: Students implement conversation memory using ChatGPT session blocks: maintaining context across multiple exchanges, clearing context when needed, and managing conversation flow. They learn about stateful vs. stateless AI interactions.

new_skills.title: Design an AI-Enhanced Development Workflow
new_skills.description: Students document their personal workflow for using AI tools during development: when to use XO vs. ChatGPT blocks vs. DALL-E vs. manual coding. They create a decision tree and justify their choices. This is a metacognitive reflection on AI-assisted development.

skill_modifications.rationale: Only need XO access + prior T24 skill. Don't need loops, events, variables, motion.
Linear progression in T24
Linear progression in T24

skill_modifications.current_description: Students design a simple AI helper (e.g., a recommendation system for books or a homework helper) and describe: (1) who it's meant to help, (2) what it does, (3) who else might use it, and (4) who it might NOT help well. They learn to think about different users when designing AI.
skill_modifications.new_description: Given a simple AI helper example (e.g., a reading buddy), students identify: (1) who it's for, (2) who else might use it, (3) who it might not help well. They learn to think about different users when evaluating AI.
skill_modifications.rationale: Designing a recommendation system is too advanced for G3. Analysis before design.
Only need prior T24 + basic sequencing
Linear progression in T24

skill_modifications.current_description: Students learn that XO sometimes gives generic answers or slightly incorrect suggestions, especially for CreatiCode-specific features or edge cases. They practice saying 'That suggestion doesn't fit my project' or asking a peer/teacher instead. This builds critical thinking and prevents over-reliance on AI.
skill_modifications.new_description: Students learn that XO has limitations: it may give generic answers, not know CreatiCode-specific features, or suggest solutions that don't fit the project context. They practice identifying when XO doesn't know and when to ask peers or teachers instead. This builds critical thinking and prevents over-reliance on AI.
skill_modifications.rationale: Merges with T24.G5.04 (redundant). Expands to cover all limitations.
Need loops + events for comparing algorithms, but not variables/motion/operators
Linear progression in T24
Need prior T24 + collaboration for peer feedback

Linear progression in T24
Linear progression in T24

skill_modifications.new_description: Students develop an AI application as a capstone project, integrating all ethical AI practices learned: (1) full model card, (2) fairness evaluation, (3) bias mitigation, (4) usage guidelines, (5) transparency documentation. This is a multi-week project demonstrating mastery of ethical AI development. NOTE: This is a capstone project, not a single-day skill assessment.
skill_modifications.rationale: Clarify this is a multi-week project to set appropriate expectations

open_questions.question: Should we add ML/KNN skills to T24 or create new T25?
open_questions.context: CreatiCode has 2 KNN blocks + 7 TensorFlow blocks for machine learning
options: Add to T24 as 'non-generative AI tools'
Add to T23 as 'AI perception and learning'

open_questions.question: Should we add RAG/Semantic Search skills to T24 or T22?
open_questions.context: CreatiCode has 3 Pinecone vector database blocks for semantic search
options: Add to T24 as 'advanced chatbot feature'
Add to T22 'AI Chatbots' as information retrieval

open_questions.question: Should we add Web Search skills to T24 or T22?
open_questions.context: CreatiCode has 1 Google Search API block
options: Add to T24 as 'AI-enhanced development tool'

open_questions.question: Should we add Content Moderation skills to T24?
options: Add to T22 as 'responsible chatbot design'
Add to T21 as 'safe content creation'

open_questions.question: Should AI Ethics skills consolidate into T26?
open_questions.context: Ethics skills currently spread across T21-T24 (.05 skills in each grade)
options: Keep ethics distributed across AI topics
Hybrid: Keep some in T24, create T26 for advanced ethics

open_questions.question: Should skills reference specific tools or be generic?
open_questions.context: Current skills explicitly mention XO, ChatGPT, DALL-E - what if tools change?
options: Keep specific tool names (matches platform reality)
Hybrid: Specific in title, generic in assessment
